safety_precautions: Wear insulated gloves to prevent electric shock.
Use safety goggles to protect eyes from debris.
Ensure the vehicle is powered off and the key is removed from the ignition.
Follow lockout/tagout procedures to ensure high-voltage systems are de-energized.
Be aware of the weight of the battery module; use proper lifting techniques or mechanical aids.
required_tools: Torque wrench (set to 30 Nm for fasteners)
Insulated socket set (for high-voltage connections)
Battery module lifting tool or hoist
Multimeter (for voltage verification)
Safety knife (for packaging removal)
steps: 1. Prepare the rear compartment by removing any covers or obstructions.
2. Carefully lift the battery module using the lifting tool or hoist, ensuring it is stable.
3. Position the battery module into the rear compartment, aligning it with the mounting brackets.
4. Secure the battery module by inserting the fasteners into the designated holes.
5. Using the torque wrench, tighten each fastener to a torque specification of 30 Nm.
6. Connect the high-voltage harness to the battery module, ensuring a secure and proper fit.
7. Verify the connection by checking for any visible gaps or misalignments.
8. Use a multimeter to check the voltage at the battery terminals to ensure proper connection.
9. Replace any covers or panels that were removed during the installation process.
acceptance_checks: Check that all fasteners are torqued to 30 Nm; any fastener not meeting this specification fails.
Inspect the high-voltage harness connection for secure fit; any loose connection fails.
Verify that the voltage reading at the battery terminals is within the expected range (e.g., 400-450V); readings outside this range fail.
Ensure no physical damage is present on the battery module or harness; any damage fails the inspection.
description: Install the battery module in the rear compartment, connect to the high-voltage harness, and verify torque on fasteners.

safety_precautions: Wear safety glasses to protect eyes from debris.
Use gloves to prevent skin contact with chemicals.
Ensure the vehicle is securely parked and cannot roll.
Be aware of the surrounding area to avoid tripping hazards.
Follow all electrical safety protocols when connecting/disconnecting sensors.
required_tools: Calibration tool kit including alignment targets
Torque wrench with a range of 0-100 Nm
Digital multimeter for electrical checks
Laptop with calibration software installed
Measuring tape (at least 3 meters long)
Leveling tool to ensure proper alignment
steps: Park the vehicle on a flat, level surface to ensure accurate calibration.
Remove any obstructions from the front bumper area to access the radar sensors.
Using the measuring tape, measure 1 meter from the front of the vehicle and mark this point on the ground.
Position the factory alignment targets at the marked point, ensuring they are level and stable.
Connect the calibration tool to the vehicle's OBD-II port to access the ADAS system.
Launch the calibration software on the laptop and follow the on-screen instructions to initiate the calibration process.
Adjust the radar sensor's angle using the torque wrench to the specified torque of 30 Nm as per the manufacturer's specifications.
Verify the alignment of the radar sensors with the targets using the leveling tool.
Complete the calibration process in the software and save the settings.
Disconnect the calibration tool and ensure all tools are removed from the vehicle.
acceptance_checks: Check that the radar sensor is aligned within ±1 degree of the specified angle.
Verify that the calibration software indicates a successful calibration with no error codes.
Ensure that the alignment targets are positioned correctly and stable during the calibration process.
Confirm that all connections are secure and that there are no loose wires or components.
Perform a functional test of the ADAS system to ensure it operates correctly post-calibration.
description: Calibrate the ADAS (Advanced Driver Assistance Systems) radar sensors on the front bumper using factory alignment targets.

safety_precautions: Wear safety goggles to protect eyes from splashes.
Use gloves to prevent skin contact with sealant.
Ensure proper ventilation in the work area to avoid inhaling fumes.
Follow all Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) guidelines for the sealant.
required_tools: Airless spray gun for even application of sealant.
Paintbrush for detailed areas and touch-ups.
Masking tape to protect areas not to be sealed.
Drop cloths to catch any drips or spills.
Personal protective equipment (PPE) including gloves, goggles, and respirator.
steps: Prepare the work area by laying down drop cloths to protect the floor.
Use masking tape to cover any areas on the door panels that should not receive sealant.
Inspect all exposed welds on the door panels for cleanliness and ensure they are free of rust and debris.
Set up the airless spray gun according to the manufacturer's specifications, ensuring the nozzle size is appropriate for the sealant being used.
Apply the anti-corrosion sealant evenly to all exposed welds, maintaining a distance of 6-12 inches from the surface.
For areas that are difficult to reach with the spray gun, use a paintbrush to apply sealant directly to the welds.
Allow the sealant to cure as per the manufacturer's instructions, typically 30 minutes to 1 hour before handling.
Remove masking tape carefully to avoid pulling off any sealant.
Inspect the application for even coverage and ensure no welds are left exposed.
acceptance_checks: Check that all exposed welds have a uniform layer of sealant without gaps.
Verify that the sealant has cured properly and is not tacky to the touch.
Ensure that no areas were missed during application, particularly in corners and crevices.
Confirm that masking tape was removed cleanly without damaging the surrounding paint.
description: Apply anti-corrosion sealant to all exposed welds on the door panels before painting.

safety_precautions: Wear safety goggles to protect eyes from coolant splashes.
Use gloves to prevent skin contact with coolant, which can be harmful.
Ensure the work area is well-ventilated to avoid inhaling fumes.
Be cautious of hot engine components; allow the engine to cool before starting the test.
required_tools: Coolant pressure tester with a gauge capable of measuring up to 30 psi.
Radiator cap adapter compatible with the vehicle's radiator.
Digital thermometer to monitor coolant temperature.
Recording device (notepad or digital device) for documenting pressure readings.
steps: Ensure the vehicle is parked on a level surface and the engine is cool.
Remove the radiator cap carefully to avoid pressure release injuries.
Attach the coolant pressure tester to the radiator neck using the appropriate adapter.
Pump the pressure tester to the specified pressure of 15 psi, as per manufacturer specifications.
Observe the pressure gauge for any drop in pressure over a 5-minute period.
If the pressure drops, inspect the coolant system for leaks, including hoses, connections, and the radiator itself.
Record the initial pressure reading and any observations regarding leaks.
If no leaks are found, release the pressure slowly and remove the tester.
Replace the radiator cap securely after the test is complete.
acceptance_checks: Initial pressure reading should be 15 psi; pass if within ±1 psi of this value.
No pressure drop should occur within 5 minutes; pass if pressure remains stable.
Visual inspection for leaks should show no signs of coolant escaping; pass if no leaks are detected.
description: Perform leak test on coolant system after radiator installation. Record pressure readings and verify against specifications.

safety_precautions: Wear anti-static wrist strap to prevent electrostatic discharge (ESD) damage to the ECU.
Ensure the work area is clean and free of any conductive materials.
Follow lockout/tagout procedures when working with electrical systems.
required_tools: Laptop with ECU programming software installed
OBD-II diagnostic tool for connectivity testing
USB cable for connecting the laptop to the ECU
Anti-static wrist strap
steps: 1. Power off the vehicle and disconnect the battery to ensure safety.
2. Connect the laptop to the infotainment ECU using the USB cable.
3. Launch the ECU programming software on the laptop.
4. Select the latest software package from the software repository.
5. Follow the on-screen instructions to upload the software package to the ECU.
6. Once the upload is complete, disconnect the USB cable.
7. Reconnect the vehicle battery and power on the vehicle.
8. Use the OBD-II diagnostic tool to check for any error codes.
9. Validate connectivity by navigating through the dashboard display and ensuring all infotainment features are operational.
acceptance_checks: Check for any error codes using the OBD-II diagnostic tool; pass if no error codes are present.
Verify that the infotainment system boots up correctly and displays the main menu; pass if the main menu is displayed within 10 seconds.
Test all connectivity features (Bluetooth, USB, etc.) to ensure they function correctly; pass if all features connect without issues.
description: Program the infotainment ECU with the latest software package and validate connectivity with dashboard display.
